docs.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to disclose a history of sexual assault to family members and more.
docs.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to disclose a history of sexual assault to family members and more.
docs.lead_paragraph: In light of the #MeToo movement and all the people coming forward about sexual assault, my father recently asked my sister if she had ever been assaulted. I myself was assaulted by the son of close family friends when I was a child, but I have never told my family about it. I am scared that my father may ask me if I was ever assaulted as he asked my sister. I don’t want to lie to him, but at the same time I’m really not ready to talk about it yet with my family, especially because I know it will be hard for my parents to hear, and it will drastically alter our relationship with our close family friends. Can I lie to my father if he asks me, or should I tell the truth? Name Withheld

headline.main: Do I Have to Tell My Father About My #MeToo Experience?

docs.abstract: In this issue, how a generation of teenagers is using online porn as sex ed.
docs.snippet: In this issue, how a generation of teenagers is using online porn as sex ed.
docs.lead_paragraph: Gail Bichler, design director: “For our cover story about what ubiquitous online pornography is teaching kids about sex, we went to the artist Sara Cwynar, who often manipulates found imagery in her work. Her magnified technicolor transformations of internet porn speak to the confusion and distortion that teenagers can experience when porn is the only real sexual education they receive.”

byline.original: By The New York Times Magazine

docs.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist column on a parent’s duty to weigh the benefit of college against the cost and what is owed to a fixer in a war-torn country.
docs.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist column on a parent’s duty to weigh the benefit of college against the cost and what is owed to a fixer in a war-torn country.
docs.lead_paragraph: I dreamed of my daughter attending a “highly selective” university, in part for the door-opening advantages these schools provide. But I recently lost my job, and though my savings can cover my retirement, I have less than I planned on. My daughter is likely to be admitted to a highly selective program but unlikely to receive aid. She could attend a local university essentially for free. The cost for the elite college that she is considering will run close to $300,000. I can cover the tuition, but it would be a sizable hit. I have told her that she alone will decide where she goes to school. She has expressed a strong desire to attend an in-state school. I feel guilty that I’m not pushing her to consider only the elite schools but also secretly hoping that she stays local. What are your thoughts? Name Withheld

headline.main: Do I Have to Spring for My Kid to Go to an Elite College?
headline.print_headline: Do I Have to Spring for My Kid to Go to an Elite College?

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

docs.abstract: What are we leaving out when we encourage one another to speak rationally, objectively and impersonally?
docs.snippet: What are we leaving out when we encourage one another to speak rationally, objectively and impersonally?
docs.lead_paragraph: — From “After Kathy Acker: A Literary Biography” (Semiotext(e)/Active Agents, 2017, Page 31), by Chris Kraus, author of the increasingly celebrated 1997 novel “I Love Dick.”

headline.main: New Sentences: From ‘After Kathy Acker,’ by Chris Kraus
headline.print_headline: ‘When She Talks, They Accuse Her of Personalizing.’

docs.abstract: Avoid eating candy to stay awake. Cut off the caffeine five hours before you plan to sleep.
docs.snippet: Avoid eating candy to stay awake. Cut off the caffeine five hours before you plan to sleep.
docs.lead_paragraph: “Beware of the deep dark,” says Teresa Wren, who has worked the night shift for 30 years as a labor-and-delivery nurse at the University of Washington Medical Center in Seattle. With sufficient sleep during the day, you can stay alert, but you’ll have to get through a wave of fatigue between 2 a.m. and 4 a.m. Take a short nap if you can. Wren warns against eating unhealthful snacks or candy to stay awake; her go-to weapons against the darkness are one caffeinated diet soda per night and a walk up and down the external stairwell in the cool air.

headline.main: How to Work a Night Shift
headline.print_headline: How to Work a Night Shift

docs.lead_paragraph: Jessica writes: Recently, I brought home three bagels from an office gathering. My boyfriend, Kelly, was going to take one for his lunch, but our dog stole it. So Kelly took the remaining two bagels (one plain, one Asiago) and is still annoyed at having “lost a bagel.” I pointed out that it had been a net gain, as technically all three were mine. Who’s right?

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Leftover Bagel Ownership
headline.kicker: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: Wearing a bandanna is like flying a flag — one that can mean almost anything you like.
docs.snippet: Wearing a bandanna is like flying a flag — one that can mean almost anything you like.
docs.lead_paragraph: I descend from a long line of Italian men who carry wads of cash in rubber bands. My grandfather, Pop, used to grab one from his pocket and count out 20s. “Buy yourself a hot dog,” he’d say, giving me 100 bucks. He was my mother’s father, a scrap-metal dealer from Newark — a working-class kid who had amassed a fortune. After he was stricken with Parkinson’s, he’d sit in his wheelchair, all 300 pounds of him, watching television or reading James Patterson on his iPad in gigantic type, sliding motionlessly toward the grave. I recall few moments when he was mobile. What I do remember is how he dressed: black gym shorts, black T-shirt, shoulder-length hair slicked back, always with a red bandanna across his forehead. He is impossible to describe without that bandanna.
